awd_titl_txt: Large Deviations and Metastability in Dynamical Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
We live in the age of networks. Our everyday lives depend on robust and predictable performance of different technological networks around us (such as power grids and communication networks). Human physiology relies on coordinated activity of hundreds of cellular networks (for example, networks of neural cells in the brain, cells in the heart and pancreas, to name a few). The patterns of connections in real world networks can be complex and exhibit nontrivial statistical properties. Understanding how the structural organization of a network affects its dynamics is the principal challenge in the theory of interacting dynamical systems that sets it apart from the theories for classical spatially extended dynamical systems, such as partial differential equations or lattice dynamical systems. The Principal Investigator (PI) seeks to develop a systematic mathematical approach to the analysis of dynamical networks. Through the development of new mathematical techniques and analyzing representative mathematical models, the PI aims to elucidate the relation between the structure and dynamics in complex networks. The PI is committed to teaching and training students. A six-month long Research Co-op for two undergraduate students will be organized in the course of this research. The PI will continue to organize minisymposia on dynamical networks at conferences on differential equations and dynamical systems.

This research advances the theory for interacting dynamical systems through the development of new theoretical results and analyzing selected models. The PI and colleagues identify new dynamical phenomena and study them using the combination of tools from graph theory, probability, and analysis. The emphasis will be on the effects of random spatial organization and noise on dynamics of large networks. The following problems are addressed: the Large Deviation Principle for interacting dynamical systems on random graphs, metastability in the continuum Kuramoto model forced by noise, and synchronization and pattern formation in the Kuramoto model with inertia. The Kuramoto model of coupled phase oscillators plays a central role in the theory of synchronization with many important applications in science and technology. In particular, the analysis of synchronization and stability of clusters developed in this research elucidates the dynamics emerging in high-voltage power grids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Networks of different kinds and scales, both natural and man-made, play an increasingly important role in science. Examples range from neuronal and genetic networks to communication networks and power grids, as well as social and economic networks, to name a few. Understanding the principles underlying collective dynamics in complex networks is critical for their prediction and control.

Interacting dynamical systems on graphs are a class of mathematical models used to elucidate collective dynamics in large networks. The PI and colleagues have developed a framework for studying dynamical systems on convergent graph sequences, specifically focusing on convergent sequences of random graphs. For networks with random connectivity, understanding large deviations from expected connectivity poses an interesting mathematical question, which has practical implications, as it enables predictions of the most likely effects of rare extreme events affecting network connectivity. The research supported by this award led to the large deviation principle for W-random graphs, providing an explicit analytical characterization of the most likely effects of large deviations on network dynamics.

Another line of research supported by this award is the analysis of synchronization and related questions in the Kuramoto model of coupled phase oscillators on graphs. Synchronization is important in various applications, including neuroscience, where it is implicated in pathologies such as Parkinson's disease and epilepsy, as well as in the mechanisms of cognitive processing and memory. Under this award, the PI and colleagues rigorously analyzed synchronization and bifurcations in the Kuramoto model with inertia on graphs. The Kuramoto model with inertia is widely used in applied science; notably, it is used in modeling power grids, where synchronization is important for efficient energy production.

A related contribution of this research is the analysis of the Turing bifurcation in the discrete Swift-Hohenberg equation on symmetric and random graphs. The Turing bifurcation provides an important mechanism of pattern formation in spatially extended models with applications to morphogenesis, population dynamics, and chemical reactions.

Finally, the approach developed for analyzing large random networks was translated into a set of numerical techniques for nonlocal diffusion equations with and without noise. These equations are  used to model  population dynamics, electrical activity in neural tissue, and porous media, to name a few applications.

Three undergraduate students were trained through six-month-long research co-ops over two years, one of which led to a published paper co-authored by a student.
